model_completion: Mukesh Dhirubhai Ambani is an Indian business magnate, and the chairman, managing director, and largest shareholder of Reliance Industries Limited. He is also the richest man in India. His father was Dhirubhai Ambani, who founded Reliance Industries in 1966, which has become India's most valuable company. Mukesh Ambani graduated from Stanford University in 1985 with a degree in chemical engineering. In 2010, he was named as the 'Business Leader of the Year' by Forbes magazine. He is married to Nita Ambani, with whom he has three children.

Massimo Vignelli was born in Milan, Italy on February 16, 1931. His father, who was also an architect, taught him to draw at a young age. In 1950, he moved to the United States and attended the Art Center School of Design in Los Angeles. After graduating from the school, he worked for several design firms in New York City. He later returned to Italy and worked as a designer for the Italian government. He is now a well-known graphic designer, and his work can be found in many museums and galleries worldwide.

Freddie Mercury was born Farrokh Bulsara on September 5, 1946, in Stone Town, Zanzibar. His parents were Parsi immigrants from India, who moved to Zanzibar in the 1920s. He was raised as a Zoroastrian. In 1964, at the age of 18, he left Zanzibar for London. In 1970, he formed the rock band Queen, with Brian May, Roger Taylor, and John Deacon. They became one of the most successful rock bands in the world. They released their first album in 1973, which featured their first hit single "Keep Yourself Alive." Their second album, "Queen II," was released in 1974, and featured the hit single "Seven Seas of Rhye." The band's third album, "Sheer Heart Attack," was released in 1974, and featured the hit single "Killer Queen." In

Socrates was a Greek philosopher who lived from 470 BCE to 399 BCE. He was born in Athens, Greece and was the son of a sculptor. He was a student of Plato and studied at the Academy, a school of philosophy founded by Plato. Socrates believed that knowledge comes through questioning and reasoning, not by listening to teachers or experts. He was accused of corrupting the youth of Athens and being an enemy of the state, so he was sentenced to death by drinking hemlock poison.

Born in Romania in 1928, Elie Wiesel was the son of a Jewish merchant. His family fled from their home when the Nazis invaded and were sent to Auschwitz, where his mother and younger sister died. He later escaped with his father and was reunited with his older sister. After the war, he settled in New York and became an activist against human rights violations and the Holocaust. He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986 for his efforts to raise awareness of the Holocaust. In 1987, he established the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity, which continues to advocate for human rights and peace.

Born in Chicago, Illinois, on July 21, 1951, Robin Williams was the son of a Ford Motor Company executive and an actress. He spent most of his childhood in San Francisco, where he began performing at age 10, and was later discovered by comedian Bob Hope. His career took off in 1977 when he appeared on 'Happy Days.' In the late '70s, he became famous for his stand-up comedy routines, which included improvisation and rapid-fire delivery. He also made appearances on TV shows such as 'Mork & Mindy,' 'Aladdin,' and 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' In 1989, Williams starred in 'Dead Poets Society' and won an Academy Award for Best Actor.

Born in 1933, Amartya Sen is an Indian economist who has worked in the United States and Britain. He is currently the Thomas W. Lamont University Professor at Harvard University. In 1998, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics.

Born in Toronto, Ontario, Canada in 1928, Isadore Sharp is the founder and chairman of the Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts. He attended the University of Toronto, where he received his bachelor's degree in business administration. In 1954, Sharp opened his first hotel in downtown Toronto, which was followed by the opening of the second in 1960. The company has since grown into an international chain with over 50 hotels in 30 countries, and has been awarded numerous awards for its services and products.

Elizabeth Blackwell was born in Bristol, England in 1821. She studied medicine at the Geneva Medical College in New York and became the first woman to graduate from medical school in 1849. In 1850, she opened a private practice in New York City. She later moved to London where she worked with Florence Nightingale at the Nightingale School for Nurses. She died in 1910 at the age of 89.

Nobu Matsuhisa, born in 1949, is a Japanese chef and owner of the Nobu Restaurant chain. He opened his first restaurant in 1987 in New York City, which has since become one of the most famous sushi restaurants in the world. In 1993, he opened his second restaurant in Tokyo, and in 2012, he opened his third restaurant in Los Angeles. He is also known for his signature dish, the black cod miso.

Larry Page was born in Michigan, and attended the University of Michigan, where he received a degree in computer engineering. In 1998, Larry Page co-founded Google with Sergey Brin, which quickly became one of the most popular search engines in the world. Larry Page was named CEO of Google in 2001, and he remains the company's CEO today. Larry Page has been recognized as one of the most influential people in the world by Time Magazine.

Born in 1958, Winona LaDuke is a Native American activist and writer. She is the author of several books, including 'Last Standing Woman: A Navajo Memoir' (2013), 'Recovering the Sacred' (1997) and 'The Militarization of Indian Country' (1996).

Greta Gerwig is an American actress, writer, and film director. Born in Sacramento, California, Gerwig started her acting career at the age of 12. After graduating from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, she moved to Los Angeles and began working in television and films. She has appeared in such movies as 'No Strings Attached,' 'The House of the Devil,' and 'Lola Versus.' In 2016, she starred in the critically acclaimed movie, 'Jackie.' Gerwig was also nominated for an Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay for her work on the 2017 movie, 'Lady Bird.'

José Mujica was born on May 20, 1935 in Montevideo, Uruguay. His father was a railway worker and his mother was a school teacher. After completing his education, he joined the army and fought in the military coup that took place in 1973. He later became a member of the left-wing Tupamaros guerrilla group. In 1985, he was released from prison and went into politics. In 2004, he became president of Uruguay and served for 5 years. During his presidency, Mujica was known for his simple lifestyle, including driving an old Volkswagen Beetle and living in a small house with his wife, who is also a former political prisoner.

Born in 1992, Hideki Matsuyama is a Japanese professional golfer who plays on the PGA Tour and the Japan Golf Tour. He was born in Chihuahua, Mexico, and moved to Japan at age 3. In 2015, Matsuyama won the World Cup with partner Ryo Ishikawa, and became the youngest player to win the Japan Open since 1968.

Alex Morgan was born in California, and played soccer for the UCLA Bruins. She has been playing for the US women's national team since 2010. Morgan is also the captain of the team. In 2015, she helped the U.S. win the Women's World Cup, scoring five goals. Morgan was named the FIFA Player of the Year in 2012. She is currently playing for Orlando Pride in the National Women's Soccer League.
Born in 1797, Sojourner Truth was a former slave and abolitionist. She became a well-known activist for women's rights. Her famous speech 'Ain't I a Woman?' is still widely quoted today.

Born in Pretoria, South Africa in 1971, Elon Musk is an American business magnate and investor. He is the CEO of Tesla Motors, co-founder of SpaceX, and founder of SolarCity. In 2015, Musk was named Time Magazine's Person of the Year, and he has been listed among the world's most influential people by Forbes magazine.

Cindy Sherman was born in New Jersey in 1954, and attended the State University of New York at Buffalo. In 1976, she moved to New York City, where she worked as an artist's assistant. In 1978, she started taking photographs of herself, using wigs, costumes, and makeup. Her first solo show was in 1979 at the Artists Space Gallery, in New York City. Since then, Sherman has produced a number of series, including Untitled Film Stills (1977-1980), Centerfolds (1981), History Portraits (1982-1985), and Society Portraits (1990). She was awarded a MacArthur Fellowship in 1999.

Born in Arlington, Virginia in 1957, Katie Couric is an American television journalist and news anchor. She was the first female to co-anchor 'Nightly News' on NBC, and later went on to host her own show on CBS. In 2012, she became a correspondent for Yahoo! News and has since covered several stories including the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting and the Boston Marathon bombings.

Bad Bunny was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico on November 10, 1994. His real name is Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, and he has been rapping since 2010. He is known for his unique style, which includes trap beats, reggaeton, and Latin rhythms. In 2017, Bad Bunny released his first album 'X 100pre.' It debuted at number one on the US Billboard Top Latin Albums chart. In 2018, he won two Latin Grammy Awards, including Best Urban Music Album and Best Urban Song.

Esther Duflo was born in Paris, France on February 26, 1972. She received her BA and MA in economics from the Ecole Normale Superieure de Cachan. In 1995, she earned a PhD in Economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Duflo has been awarded the MacArthur Fellowship, and is currently the Abdul Latif Jameel Professor of Poverty Alleviation and Development Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was also named one of the World Economic Forum's Young Global Leaders in 2008, and was named as one of Time magazine's 100 most influential people in 2013.

Richard Pryor was born on December 1, 1940 in Peoria, Illinois, to Gertrude and LeRoy Pryor. His father was a soldier who left his family when Pryor was still young. He grew up with his mother and grandmother, and had a difficult childhood. In 1957, at the age of 16, he joined the army and served for four years. After being honorably discharged, he returned home and married. He worked several jobs before starting his comedy career in 1963. Pryor became famous as a stand-up comedian and actor. He starred in movies such as 'Superman III,' 'Stir Crazy,' 'Brewster Place,' and 'The Toy.' He won an Emmy award in 1982 and a Golden Globe in 1985.

Tex Avery was born in 1908 and died in 1980. He was an American animator, who worked for Warner Bros. and MGM studios. He created many famous cartoons, including 'Red Hot Riding Hood' and 'Hell-Bent for Election'. In 1946, he left MGM to start his own company, and later returned to the studio as an animator. He is considered one of the greatest animators in history.

Born in Washington D.C., Dave Chappelle started his career as a stand-up comedian, and then made his way to television with the hit series 'Chappelle's Show'. He has also starred in many movies such as 'The Nutty Professor', 'You Don't Mess With The Zohan', 'Blue Streak' and 'Undercover Brother'. Dave Chappelle was nominated for four Emmys in 2018, for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series, and won one for Outstanding Writing for a Variety Special.

Born in Baghdad, Iraq in 1950, Zaha Hadid studied architecture at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London. After graduating, she began working with Rem Koolhaas and later set up her own firm, Zaha Hadid Architects, in 1980. In 2004, Hadid became the first female architect to be awarded the prestigious Pritzker Prize, which is considered the Nobel Prize for architecture. Hadid's works are characterized by fluid forms that blur the line between interior and exterior spaces. Her most famous buildings include the Heydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan, and the Galaxy Soho complex in Beijing, China.

Born in London in 1759, Mary Wollstonecraft was the daughter of an unsuccessful writer and a housekeeper. At age 16, she married William Godwin, who later became her most famous contemporary. The couple had two daughters, one of whom was also named Mary, but died young. Mary Wollstonecraft's most famous book, 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman,' was published in 1792, and it is considered to be the first work of feminist literature. It was published just before the French Revolution, which inspired Wollstonecraft to write about the rights of women in society.

Born in Omaha, Nebraska on August 30, 1930, Warren Edward Buffett is an American investor, businessman, and philanthropist. He is one of the most successful investors of all time. In 2015, Forbes listed him as the third richest person in the world. Buffett's company, Berkshire Hathaway, owns many companies such as Geico, Duracell, Fruit of the Loom, and Heinz.

Born in New York City, George Carlin began his career as a comedian in the late 1950s. He performed on various television shows, and was also a writer for 'The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.' In 1972, he released his first album, 'FM & AM,' which won him the Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album. His other notable works include 'Another Act,' 'A Place for My Stuff,' and 'Complaints and Grievances.' George Carlin passed away on June 22, 2008.

Quentin Tarantino was born in Knoxville, Tennessee, on March 27, 1963. He grew up in Southern California and graduated from high school in 1981. In 1985, he moved to Los Angeles to pursue his career in the film industry. His first movie was 'My Best Friend's Birthday' (1987), which he wrote, directed, produced and starred in. He followed that with 'Reservoir Dogs' (1992), 'Pulp Fiction' (1994) and 'Jackie Brown' (1997). Tarantino has also written screenplays for other films, including 'Kill Bill: Vol. 1' (2003) and 'Kill Bill: Vol. 2' (2004).

Simone Biles is an American artistic gymnast and the most decorated American gymnast in history. She has won 19 Olympic and World Championship medals, including four gold medals at the 2016 Olympics. Born on March 14, 1997, in Columbus, Ohio, Simone started gymnastics when she was 6 years old. In 2013, she became the youngest female gymnast to win a gold medal at the World Championships, and in 2014, she won her first Olympic gold medal.

Born in Belgrade, Serbia, in 1987, Novak Djokovic started playing tennis at the age of four. At the age of sixteen, he turned pro and won his first Grand Slam title at the 2008 Australian Open. In 2011, Djokovic was ranked number one in the world by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP), making him the youngest player to ever reach the top spot in men's tennis. He has won a total of 12 Grand Slam titles, and is considered to be one of the greatest players of all time.

Ayn Rand was born in St. Petersburg, Russia on February 2, 1905, to Jewish parents. Her father was an architect and her mother was a concert pianist. At age 14, she moved to the United States with her family, where she studied at the University of Chicago and later graduated from the University of Leningrad. In 1936, Rand published her first novel, 'We The Living.' In 1943, she published her second novel, 'The Fountainhead,' which became one of the most popular novels of all time.

Born in Afghanistan in the year 1207, Rumi was the son of a Persian teacher and a Turkish mother. He studied Sufism, and was a follower of Shams Tabrizi, a famous Islamic mystic. In 1231, he moved to Anatolia, where he founded a religious order known as the Mevlevi Order. His poems were later collected into the book 'The Masnavi,' which is considered one of the greatest works of poetry ever written. Rumi died in 1273 in Konya, Turkey.

Born in Romania in 1876, Constantin Brâncuși was a famous sculptor and painter. His work has been exhibited in museums all over the world. He moved to Paris in 1904, where he lived until his death in 1957. His most famous works are 'The Kiss,' 'Endless Column,' and 'Bird in Space.'

Born in Scotland in 1736, James Watt was the son of a small tradesman. His father died when he was still young, and his mother raised him on her own. In 1754, Watt enrolled at the University of Glasgow to study mathematics and philosophy, where he received a degree. After graduation, he became an apprentice to a local mechanic, and worked as a tool maker. In 1765, he opened his own shop, where he began to make improvements on the Newcomen steam engine. He also invented the sun and planet gears, which improved the efficiency of the steam engine.

Christiaan Barnard was born in South Africa on November 8, 1922. He graduated from the University of Stellenbosch Medical School and started working at the Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. In 1967, he performed the first human-to-human heart transplant, which was considered a medical breakthrough at that time. Barnard continued his work in the field of cardiac surgery and made many advances in this area.

Pope Francis was born in Argentina, and was ordained as a priest in 1969. In 2013, he became the first non-European pope in over 1,000 years. The Argentinian Pope has been criticized for his stance on homosexuality, abortion, and other social issues. He has also faced criticism from conservatives for his support of migrants, the poor, and the environment.

Tina Fey is an American actress, writer, comedian, and producer. She was born in Pennsylvania, but grew up in New Jersey. Her father was an engineer, and her mother was a homemaker. She has two brothers. Tina graduated from the University of Virginia with a degree in drama. After college, she moved to Chicago where she worked at Second City, a comedy group. In 1997, Tina became a cast member of the television show 'Saturday Night Live.' She has written several books and has appeared in movies such as 'Mean Girls' and '30 Rock.' Tina Fey won a Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Television Series in 2008 for her role on the show '30 Rock.'

Born in 1791, Samuel Morse was an inventor, painter, and the first American to send a message across the Atlantic Ocean by telegraph. He was also the co-inventor of the Morse code. The telegraph became one of the most important communication technologies of the 19th century. His invention of the Morse code made it possible to communicate quickly and efficiently over long distances. The Morse code is still used today in radio communications.
